Key.Rationale: Photographs such as this one did not provide information about schools of the time period. Ending segregation was not the goal of this photographer.

G.Choice: Document labor conditions during an economic crisis

Key.Rationale: Economic crises during the time were short-lived and did not significantly impact working conditions. Depicting the impact of an economic crisis was not the purpose of photographs such as this one.

H.Choice: Depict the evils of capitalism in communist propaganda

Key.Rationale: Photographs such as this one were not primarily intended to be used in communist publications. There was not a strong communist movement in the United States at this time.

J.Choice: Focus attention on the need for child labor reforms

Key.Rationale: By the early 1900s, concerns about child labor were gaining increasing support. Lewis Hine became an investigative photographer for the National Child Labor Committee. He traveled across the United States photographing and documenting working conditions of children. By 1916 Congress passed a law establishing child-labor standards. These laws were later expanded to increase protections for children.

Content:
:box:Lacrosse gained popularity . . . in the mid-nineteenth century . . . [in] the urban areas of New York, Philadelphia, and especially Baltimore and Annapolis. Advent of the synthetic stick and conversion of the field to a hockey-like box . . . in the 1930s made lacrosse even more popular. . . . Sporadically disappearing and reappearing, today the old native game enjoys a record following. Organized professional leagues have surfaced during the past two decades, and college intramural and varsity lacrosse, which have long thrived in the northeast, are established at state universities across the South and West.

—Anthony Aveni, Colonial Williamsburg Journal, 2010
A student could use this excerpt in a paper about the —

A.Choice: challenges of preserving American Indian traditional clothing

Key.Rationale: The excerpt is not about traditional American Indian clothing.

B.Choice: movement to reform American Indian schools

Key.Rationale: The excerpt does not reference American Indian schools.

C.Choice: contributions of American Indians to U.S. culture

Key.Rationale: Lacrosse is based on a sport first played by American Indians and then adopted by American settlers. The student could use the excerpt as one example of contributions by American Indians to U.S culture.

D.Choice: pressure on American Indians to assimilate

Key.Rationale: This excerpt demonstrates the assimilation of American Indian culture into U.S. culture, not pressure on American Indians to give up their culture.

Content: problems/TX18HSUSH/media/64a.jpg
Which action completes this cause-and-effect diagram?

F.Choice: Banks lower interest rates

Key.Rationale: Many banks in the late 1920s were raising interest rates, not lowering them.

G.Choice: Elected leaders lower tariff rates

Key.Rationale: Elected leaders raised, not lowered, tariff rates to protect domestic industry from foreign competition.

H.Choice: Companies lay off employees

Key.Rationale: In the 1920s many people purchased goods using credit-installment plans. After the stock market crashed in 1929, people were unable to make the payments on these plans. As a result the demand for goods declined, and manufacturers reduced the amount of goods they produced. Companies needed fewer employees and began to lay off people.

J.Choice: Labor unions demand higher wages

Key.Rationale: As manufacturers reduced production and were struggling, labor unions were unlikely to demand higher wages.

Content: What important military contribution did Navajo Code Talkers make during World War II?

A.Choice: They were part of a volunteer group of U.S. pilots that defended China from Japanese aggression.

Key.Rationale: The volunteer group of U.S. pilots who flew missions in China to protect against Japanese aggression were known as the Flying Tigers.

B.Choice: They were one of the groups that transmitted secret military information in the Pacific Theater.

Key.Rationale: During World War II, the Marine Corps used the Navajo language to create a secret code. This code was used to transmit military information in the Pacific Theater of the war. The men who transmitted this military information were Navajo and were known as the Navajo Code Talkers.

C.Choice: They were among the first black servicemen to fly as military aviators in the U.S. armed forces.

Key.Rationale: Members of the first squadron of African American military pilots in the U.S. Army Air Corps were known as the Tuskegee Airmen.

D.Choice: They were members of the tank division that helped liberate France after the invasion of Normandy.

Key.Rationale: The Navajo Code Talkers served in the Pacific Theater, not in France.

Content: Which box lists characteristics of the 1960s?

F.Choice:
:box:• Prohibition
• The Lost Generation
• The Harlem Renaissance
• Religious fundamentalism

Key.Rationale: These are characteristics of the 1920s.

G.Choice:
:box:• Widespread unemployment
• New Deal programs
• The Golden Age of Hollywood
• The Dust Bowl

Key.Rationale: These are characteristics of the 1930s.

H.Choice:
:box:• The counterculture
• The Civil Rights movement
• The Vietnam War
• The Space Race

Key.Rationale: The counterculture, the Civil Rights movement, the Vietnam War, and the Space Race all took place during the 1960s.

J.Choice:
:box:• Televangelists
• Neoconservatism
• Video games
• The fall of the Soviet Union

Key.Rationale: These are characteristics of the 1980s and early 1990s.

Content: problems/TX18HSUSH/media/67a.jpg
problems/TX18HSUSH/media/67b.jpg
Which action best explains the differences shown in these photographs?

A.Choice: The United States gave economic assistance through the Marshall Plan.

Key.Rationale: The photographs show a French steel plant during and after World War II. After World War II, the U.S. government implemented the European Recovery Program, more commonly known as the Marshall Plan. The plan sent more than $13 billion dollars to help rebuild and finance the recovery of western and southern European economies. The Marshall Plan helped rebuild factories like the steel plant in the photograph.

B.Choice: The United States and the Soviet Union created an alliance after World War II.

Key.Rationale: The United States and the Soviet Union became rivals after World War II. They were not in alliance.

C.Choice: U.S. leaders created the United Nations.

Key.Rationale: U.S. leaders did not create the United Nations. It was created primarily to prevent future conflicts.

D.Choice: The Soviet Union established the “Iron Curtain” after World War II.

Key.Rationale: The Iron Curtain is a name referring to the division of Europe between communist countries in Eastern Europe, under the influence of the Soviet Union, and democratic countries in Western Europe. The Iron Curtain had nothing to do with the rebuilding of the French factory in the photo.

Content: Which action is the best example of a civic responsibility?

F.Choice: Writing an editorial piece for a newspaper

Key.Rationale: Writing an editorial is protected by the First Amendment’s freedom of speech and press. Not all citizens are able to write and publish an editorial in a newspaper.

G.Choice: Volunteering to sell raffle tickets

Key.Rationale: This action is known as volunteerism, or choosing to spend time doing something for a community. The purpose of this raffle is not clear. Selling raffle tickets is not a civic responsibility.

H.Choice: Voting on election day

Key.Rationale: Voting is one of the most important duties associated with continuing the American tradition of representative government.

J.Choice: Opening a business

Key.Rationale: Opening a business is an economic activity. It is not a civic responsibility.
